p: Reunion Island is a hotspot of biodiversity with 22 plants listed in the French Pharmacopeia, widely used by the population for antioxidant, lipid-lowering and anti-inflammatory properties [ 26]. Our previous study on eight medicinal plants used in Reunion Island revealed the presence of bioactive polyphenols (such as quercetin, gallic acid, mangiferin) and antioxidant properties on in vitro models (human red blood cells and murine preadipocytes 3T3-L1) [ 27]. Ethnopharmacological studies support the interest of medicinal plant antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities in the management of different pathologies including atherosclerosis [ 28, 29, 30, 31].
